problem: I have 6 shirts, 6 pairs of pants, and 6 hats.  Each item comes in the same 6 colors (so that I have one of each item of each color).  I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color.  How many choices for outfits do I have?
solution: The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 6\times 6=216$. There are 6 outfits in which all three items are the same color. Thus there are $216-6=\boxed{210}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
model_solution:
1.  The total number of outfits, if I had no restrictions, is 6 x 6 x 6 = 216.
2.  I must subtract the number of invalid outfits, in which all 3 items are the same color.  Since there are 6 colors and each color has only one of each item, there are 6 invalid outfits.
3.  Total number of outfits = 216 - 6 = 210
4. Total number of outfits = 210
4. Total number of outfits = 210

2.  I must subtract the number of invalid outfits, in which all 3 items are the same color.  Since there are 6 colors and each color has only one of each item, there are 6 invalid outfits.

2.  I must subtract the number of invalid outfits, in which all 3 items are the same color.  Since there are 6 colors and each color has only one of each item, there are 6 invalid outfits.
